key_points: Democratic members of Congress are investigating how rioters easily breached the Capitol and targeted liberal lawmakers' offices during the Jan. 6 riot.
Speculation includes that members of Congress or their staff may have facilitated the breach by organizing pre-riot tours and removing emergency call buttons from offices.
Over 30 members of Congress signed a letter demanding an investigation into the alleged pre-riot tours and possible collaboration.
Rioters seemed to have specific knowledge of the Capitol's layout, targeting the offices of high-profile Democrats such as Nancy Pelosi.
Claims from 'Stop the Steal' organizer Ali Alexander suggest involvement from Republican House members Andy Biggs, Paul Gosar, and Mo Brooks in planning the rally.
Investigations are requested from the House Sergeant at Arms, Senate Sergeant at Arms, and Capitol Police, with unclear progress.
U.S. Rep. Mikie Sherrill claims without proper credentials from Congress members, the rioters couldn't have entered the Capitol.
U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan heard names of lawmakers who gave tours but awaits verification before disclosing them.
U.S. Rep. Vern Buchanan and Rep. Tom Emmer express skepticism and denials regarding the allegations.
Lawmakers and investigators have not disclosed specific evidence linking the tours to the riot or the targeting of specific offices.
spokespersons: U.S. Rep. Mikie Sherrill (Democrat, New Jersey)
